p: Smallholdersâ€™ abilities to manage climatic risks can be shaped by how well they navigate shifts in agricultural policy ( Eakin, 2005) and there is arguably a need to make climate risk management a central feature of development planning ( Agrawal & Lemos, 2015). To create opportunities for equitable adaptation to climate change, it is increasingly recognized as essential to address deeply rooted structural inequities and power differentials that have implications for distributive justice ( Bassett and Fogelman, 2013, Pelling, 2011, Shinn et al., 2014, Turner, 2016, Tschakert et al., 2013). To illuminate such power differentials and how they shape adaptation options, burgeoning work focuses on the lived experiences of smallholders via in-depth empirical assessments of adaptation processes ( Burnham and Ma, 2017, Eakin et al., 2009, Feola et al., 2015, Nightingale, 2017, Shinn, 2016).
